full_text: And (2) FCPA works because it makes bribing a foreign official a *crime* which means if you meet the elements laid out in the statute (and interpreted over time by the courts), you're per se facing jail time, fines or both. See, e.g., Vitol settlement: https://t.co/apMjSjaFgy /5

full_text: Without getting into the jurisprudence of extraterritorial criminal jurisdiction, two points worth noting: (1) FCPA was drafted because @SEC_News conducted an investigation, found a ton of international bribery by US firms, but couldn't do anything about it under existing law. /4
full_text(utf-8): b"Without getting into the jurisprudence of extraterritorial criminal jurisdiction, two points worth noting: (1) FCPA was drafted because @SEC_News conducted an investigation, found a ton of international bribery by US firms, but couldn't do anything about it under existing law. /4"

full_text: The FCPA is an extraterritorial criminal statute that makes it illegal for US firms to bribe foreign officials. Congress passed it in 1977 in response to genuinely outrageous behavior by Lockheed. Notably, until 2010 or so, the US was alone in criminalizing foreign bribes. /3
full_text(utf-8): b'The FCPA is an extraterritorial criminal statute that makes it illegal for US firms to bribe foreign officials. Congress passed it in 1977 in response to genuinely outrageous behavior by Lockheed. Notably, until 2010 or so, the US was alone in criminalizing foreign bribes. /3'

full_text: 13/ Showing how far #scenarioanalysis debate has come since #TCFDRecs, the report calls for scenarios that a) capture broad impacts but with a focus on materiality, b) map macroeconomic & financial transmission mechanisms, and c) account for "adaptation" to the extent feasible!

full_text: 12/ The CFTC #climaterisk report also nods to the important "Inevitable Policy Response" work of @PRI_News, calling for financial regulators to "analyze a scenario involving a major policy disruption" because "unanticipated policies can abruptly strand long-lived capital assets."
full_text(utf-8): b'12/ The CFTC #climaterisk report also nods to the important "Inevitable Policy Response" work of @PRI_News, calling for financial regulators to "analyze a scenario involving a major policy disruption" because "unanticipated policies can abruptly strand long-lived capital assets."'

full_text: 11/ Wading into the scenario analysis debate, the report calls for financial regulators to use more than one scenario, and points to "well below 2 degrees," current trajectory, & something "in between." This is not surprising given cmte membership, but will still disappoint many!
full_text(utf-8): b'11/ Wading into the scenario analysis debate, the report calls for financial regulators to use more than one scenario, and points to "well below 2 degrees," current trajectory, & something "in between." This is not surprising given cmte membership, but will still disappoint many!'

full_text:
10/ Data! Regulators should work with private sector to support a "range of platforms for climate
data and analysis," including "new and existing
open source platforms, as well as proprietary efforts to develop new climate risk datasets and tools." More #climatetech VC activity?
full_text(utf-8): b'10/ Data! Regulators should work with private sector to support a "range of platforms for climate\ndata and analysis," including "new and existing\nopen source platforms, as well as proprietary efforts to develop new climate risk datasets and tools." More #climatetech VC activity?'

full_text: 9/ Report calls for the US to follow the lead of international counterparts who've already begun to conduct climate risk stress tests against common scenarios... and yet... the Bank of England has delayed its much-anticipated stress test due to Covid. Ugh! https://t.co/5f0H5HqwLh
full_text(utf-8): b"9/ Report calls for the US to follow the lead of international counterparts who've already begun to conduct climate risk stress tests against common scenarios... and yet... the Bank of England has delayed its much-anticipated stress test due to Covid. Ugh! https://t.co/5f0H5HqwLh"

full_text: 8/ Climate risk stress testing! Financial regulators should conduct stress tests of bank & insurer balance sheets "against a common set of scenarios." Notably, agricultural, community banks & non-systemically important regional banks should be included, not just the big banks.
full_text(utf-8): b'8/ Climate risk stress testing! Financial regulators should conduct stress tests of bank & insurer balance sheets "against a common set of scenarios." Notably, agricultural, community banks & non-systemically important regional banks should be included, not just the big banks.'

full_text: 7/ Speaking of NGFS, the CFTC #climaterisk report urges US financial regulators to get back in the international governance game, calling for the US to join, "as full members," the NGFS, Coalition of Finance Ministers for Climate Action, and the Sustainable Insurance Forum (SIF).
full_text(utf-8): b'7/ Speaking of NGFS, the CFTC #climaterisk report urges US financial regulators to get back in the international governance game, calling for the US to join, "as full members," the NGFS, Coalition of Finance Ministers for Climate Action, and the Sustainable Insurance Forum (SIF).'

full_text: 6/ Notable: Financial regulators should dig into climate-related ‚Äúsub-systemic‚Äù shocks to financial markets & institutions in particular sectors/regions. This moves well beyond @FSB_TCFD & @NGFS_, which are limited by the macroprudential "systemic risk" mandate of central banks
full_text(utf-8): b'6/ Notable: Financial regulators should dig into climate-related \xe2\x80\x9csub-systemic\xe2\x80\x9d shocks to financial markets & institutions in particular sectors/regions. This moves well beyond @FSB_TCFD & @NGFS_, which are limited by the macroprudential "systemic risk" mandate of central banks'

full_text: 5/ Next big rec: FSOC, created after the last financial crisis, should "incorporate climate-related financial risks into its existing oversight function, including its annual reports and other reporting to Congress."
full_text(utf-8): b'5/ Next big rec: FSOC, created after the last financial crisis, should "incorporate climate-related financial risks into its existing oversight function, including its annual reports and other reporting to Congress."'

full_text: 4/ First big recommendation is a no brainer but also doesn't tell us much: US should put a price on carbon. No details on what that price should be, or how it should be implemented (cap & dividend, etc). Report author @NatKeohane & his team at @EnvDefenseFund have much to say tho
full_text(utf-8): b"4/ First big recommendation is a no brainer but also doesn't tell us much: US should put a price on carbon. No details on what that price should be, or how it should be implemented (cap & dividend, etc). Report author @NatKeohane & his team at @EnvDefenseFund have much to say tho"

full_text: 3/ Notably, the CFTC #climaterisk report does not just make recommendations to the CFTC, and is not limited by the jurisdiction of this agency (commodities, derivatives markets, etc). Also notable: the recommendations aren't binding. If Biden wins, they'll be a blueprint at best.
full_text(utf-8): b"3/ Notably, the CFTC #climaterisk report does not just make recommendations to the CFTC, and is not limited by the jurisdiction of this agency (commodities, derivatives markets, etc). Also notable: the recommendations aren't binding. If Biden wins, they'll be a blueprint at best."

full_text: 2/ Topline message: "US financial regulators must recognize that climate change poses serious emerging risks to the US financial system, and they should move urgently and decisively to measure, understand, and address these risks." Full report here (PDF): https://t.co/TgKFF3snoG

full_text: Second, if history is any guide, major US foreign policy priorities (and yes, climate is going to eventually be at the top of the list!) are managed by State and NSC. Veeps tend to get sent out on special assignments, as Biden did under Obama, but don't shape policy (cf Cheney).

full_text:
There are 2 reasons why:

First, despite her campaign positions, Harris (unlike say, Susan Rice) just isn't a foreign policy person. She doesn't sit on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee (unlike say, Biden, who chaired it before going on to Veep-hood).

full_text: 9) Big picture, the ‚Äúclimate community‚Äù must expand to include everyone. It‚Äôs the megatrend shaping our world for the next 10,000 yrs. How could it not include all of us? If you find yourself policing language or drawing lines around *your* way of doing #climateaction, just stop!
full_text(utf-8): b'9) Big picture, the \xe2\x80\x9cclimate community\xe2\x80\x9d must expand to include everyone. It\xe2\x80\x99s the megatrend shaping our world for the next 10,000 yrs. How could it not include all of us? If you find yourself policing language or drawing lines around *your* way of doing #climateaction, just stop!'

full_text: 8) So how to fix what‚Äôs broken? As @JaneAFlegal points out, the outdated language & institutional arrangements being propagated by those who have a stake in *the way climate politics used to be done* are hindering our ability to build power to truly tackle the climate crisis!
full_text(utf-8): b'8) So how to fix what\xe2\x80\x99s broken? As @JaneAFlegal points out, the outdated language & institutional arrangements being propagated by those who have a stake in *the way climate politics used to be done* are hindering our ability to build power to truly tackle the climate crisis!'

full_text: 7) But as in every human institution, there‚Äôs major path dependency in our language, and therefore our politics and our mental model of the world. ‚ÄúAdaptation‚Äù and ‚Äúmitigation‚Äù have 20+ years of history behind them, plus major institutions & stakeholders bought into this frame.
full_text(utf-8): b'7) But as in every human institution, there\xe2\x80\x99s major path dependency in our language, and therefore our politics and our mental model of the world. \xe2\x80\x9cAdaptation\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cmitigation\xe2\x80\x9d have 20+ years of history behind them, plus major institutions & stakeholders bought into this frame.'

full_text: 6) Fast forward to 2020, and adaptation isn‚Äôt speculative & it‚Äôs no longer constrained to developing countries (obv it never was!) Today it means the end of the 30-year mortgage market in Florida, or PG&E‚Äôs wildfire-induced criminal liability. It means real suffering in US cities
full_text(utf-8): b'6) Fast forward to 2020, and adaptation isn\xe2\x80\x99t speculative & it\xe2\x80\x99s no longer constrained to developing countries (obv it never was!) Today it means the end of the 30-year mortgage market in Florida, or PG&E\xe2\x80\x99s wildfire-induced criminal liability. It means real suffering in US cities'

full_text: 5) And for good reason! Even back then it was obvious that climate impacts would hit first & hardest in those communities, regions and countries where people were least able to cope & where they had done the least to cause the problem. Adaptation was a huge diplomatic priority!
full_text(utf-8): b'5) And for good reason! Even back then it was obvious that climate impacts would hit first & hardest in those communities, regions and countries where people were least able to cope & where they had done the least to cause the problem. Adaptation was a huge diplomatic priority!'

full_text: 4) The problem back then was one part intellectual ‚Äî what to call these new concepts/categories ‚Äî and one part political ‚Äî who‚Äôs on the hook for what, legally & financially speaking? Developing counties & their green allies insisted on dedicated funds earmarked for adapatation.
full_text(utf-8): b'4) The problem back then was one part intellectual \xe2\x80\x94 what to call these new concepts/categories \xe2\x80\x94 and one part political \xe2\x80\x94 who\xe2\x80\x99s on the hook for what, legally & financially speaking? Developing counties & their green allies insisted on dedicated funds earmarked for adapatation.'

full_text: 3) When I attended COP6 in 2000, the entire apparatus of the UNFCCC and the overwhelming majority of the energy, resources, bandwidth and white papers was focused on cutting emissions ‚Äî mitigation. Adaptation was thought of, if at all, as a distant problem, both in time & space.
full_text(utf-8): b'3) When I attended COP6 in 2000, the entire apparatus of the UNFCCC and the overwhelming majority of the energy, resources, bandwidth and white papers was focused on cutting emissions \xe2\x80\x94 mitigation. Adaptation was thought of, if at all, as a distant problem, both in time & space.'

full_text: 2) But in 1997, when the @UNFCCC COP negotiations yielded the #KyotoProtocol, there absolutely *was* a climate community: scientists (IPCC), diplomats (UNFCCC) and environmental NGOs. And these folks had good reasons to distinguish btw mitigation (present) & adaptation (future).
full_text(utf-8): b'2) But in 1997, when the @UNFCCC COP negotiations yielded the #KyotoProtocol, there absolutely *was* a climate community: scientists (IPCC), diplomats (UNFCCC) and environmental NGOs. full_text: 6/ Unfortunately, an overly prescriptive, rules-based approach to #SustainableFinance in the EU draft seems to yield irrational results, where one fossil fuel is "in" and another is "out" of a category... with all sorts of unintended consequences.
full_text(utf-8): b'6/ Unfortunately, an overly prescriptive, rules-based approach to #SustainableFinance in the EU draft seems to yield irrational results, where one fossil fuel is "in" and another is "out" of a category... with all sorts of unintended consequences.'

full_text: 5/ For instance, California's #AB32 climate law & its low-carbon fuel standard, take pains to look at lifecycle GHG emissions across the value chain of all fuels. That way,  perverse outcomes can be avoided (like corn-based ethanol with higher emissions than gasoline!) #LCFS
full_text(utf-8): b"5/ For instance, California's #AB32 climate law & its low-carbon fuel standard, take pains to look at lifecycle GHG emissions across the value chain of all fuels. That way,  perverse outcomes can be avoided (like corn-based ethanol with higher emissions than gasoline!) #LCFS"

full_text: 4/ This is not to say a US approach would be perfect. Far from it! But as in so many other cases, we might have crafted a more principles-based framework that captures the intent of the regulation: investors must disclose the full climate impact of their investments.
full_text(utf-8): b'4/ This is not to say a US approach would be perfect. Far from it! But as in so many other cases, we might have crafted a more principles-based framework that captures the intent of the regulation: investors must disclose the full climate impact of their investments.'

full_text: 3/ Yet without US capital markets regulators like SEC/CFTC/Treasury/Fed in the game, we're stuck with a very European, prescriptive approach to #SustainableFinance regulation... e.g. treating "solid" fossil fuels like coal differently than oil & gas. https://t.co/IhrELRP9xx

full_text:
TL;DR 

1) EU TEG's #sustainablefinance taxonomy will help drive capital to climate-friendly activities. 

2) It'd be great if US regulation were moving in the same direction, as many investors find EU rules cumbersome and capital markets are global.

3) If you're American: VOTE!
full_text(utf-8):
b"TL;DR 

1) EU TEG's #sustainablefinance taxonomy will help drive capital to climate-friendly activities. 

2) It'd be great if US regulation were moving in the same direction, as many investors find EU rules cumbersome and capital markets are global.

3) If you're American: VOTE!"

full_text: Finally, I'd be remiss if I didn't point out the flip side of the coin when it comes to US common law and judicial review: Trump's recent appointments to federal appellate courts may make some of these potential #sustainablefinance regulations more vulnerable to challenges. /9
full_text(utf-8): b"Finally, I'd be remiss if I didn't point out the flip side of the coin when it comes to US common law and judicial review: Trump's recent appointments to federal appellate courts may make some of these potential #sustainablefinance regulations more vulnerable to challenges. /9"

full_text: As a helpful guide to what US regulators might (will?) do under a future climate-friendly administration, see Senator Warren's most recent policy package on financial markets and climate: https://t.co/nySVnbYzVC. This may not all be implemented, but much of it will... /8
full_text(utf-8): b"As a helpful guide to what US regulators might (will?) do under a future climate-friendly administration, see Senator Warren's most recent policy package on financial markets and climate: https://t.co/nySVnbYzVC. This may not all be implemented, but much of it will... /8"

full_text: One consequence of Trump's disastrous, disheartening inaction on climate change is that the US financial regulatory apparatus has effectively ceded the field to the EU. They've done an admirable job in our absence, but until the US weighs in, investors face patchwork rules. /7
full_text(utf-8): b"One consequence of Trump's disastrous, disheartening inaction on climate change is that the US financial regulatory apparatus has effectively ceded the field to the EU. They've done an admirable job in our absence, but until the US weighs in, investors face patchwork rules. /7"

full_text: As the only game in town (for now), the EU approach may prove less effective in driving capital to sustainable, climate-friendly activities... because it speaks the language of EU civil law, not the language of global capital markets regulation, e.g. US (& UK) common law. /6
full_text(utf-8): b'As the only game in town (for now), the EU approach may prove less effective in driving capital to sustainable, climate-friendly activities... because it speaks the language of EU civil law, not the language of global capital markets regulation, e.g. US (& UK) common law. /6'

full_text: By contrast, the EU TEG has taken a civil law approach to its #sustainablefinance taxonomy, which looks more like a detailed set of rules & standards where everything is codified in statute. This is not to say the taxonomy is unworkable or cumbersome. Far from it! However... /5
full_text(utf-8): b'By contrast, the EU TEG has taken a civil law approach to its #sustainablefinance taxonomy, which looks more like a detailed set of rules & standards where everything is codified in statute. This is not to say the taxonomy is unworkable or cumbersome. Far from it! However... /5'

full_text: When it comes to financial markets & #ESG #climaterisk #sustainablefinance disclosure, US regulators would take a principles-based approach, applying a materiality screen for disclosures that would strike the right balance for all stakeholders. If not, the courts would do so. /4
full_text(utf-8): b'When it comes to financial markets & #ESG #climaterisk #sustainablefinance disclosure, US regulators would take a principles-based approach, applying a materiality screen for disclosures that would strike the right balance for all stakeholders. If not, the courts would do so. /4'

full_text: In the US, Congress passes vague statutes (e.g. Dodd-Frank) & federal agencies like SEC or CFTC promulgate regulations implementing these laws. Rules are subject to notice & comment and are reviewable in court, where judges can apply precedent and police regulatory overreach. /3
full_text(utf-8): b'In the US, Congress passes vague statutes (e.g. Dodd-Frank) & federal agencies like SEC or CFTC promulgate regulations implementing these laws. Rules are subject to notice & comment and are reviewable in court, where judges can apply precedent and police regulatory overreach. /3'

full_text: ...I bemoan the lack of US leadership on these critically important issues to the future of the global economy! As any international lawyer knows, the EU operates under civil law, while the US (and UK) is a common law jurisdictions. What does this mean for #sustainablefinance? /2
full_text(utf-8): b'...I bemoan the lack of US leadership on these critically important issues to the future of the global economy! As any international lawyer knows, the EU operates under civil law, while the US (and UK) is a common law jurisdictions. What does this mean for #sustainablefinance? /2'

full_text(utf-8):
b'@_ppmv @kmac @AlexSteffen A few answers off the top of my head:

1) They\xe2\x80\x99re both important. Lots of folks still fighting to make Amazon greener, but the Bezos announcement is new & therefore \xe2\x80\x9cnews.\xe2\x80\x9d

b'@James_BG 2 sides of the coin:

Pro: You can\xe2\x80\x99t do a thing until you name the thing you\xe2\x80\x99re trying to do. Hence: #NetZero

Con: Humans, especially on social media, have tiny attention spans and will always flock to the next new thing... today: #NetZero https://t.co/CqRRqG1ts5'
